content.raw: `InitialModelSdf` sounds good :thumbsup:
content.html: InitialModelSdf sounds good

content.raw:
Yeah, that's a valid concern. I was not thinking `ModelSdf` will be kept up to date, so calling it `InitialModelSdf` makes sense. On further thought, maybe we should stick with creating a component for `<self_collide>`. My reason for adding `ModelSdf` for saving world files was to retrieve the SDF's file path, but that can be kept in a `SdfFilePath` component. I also now realize that we won't be able to properly serialize `sdf::Model` because it needs a pointer to it's `sdf::World` for frame semantics.

Edit: Sorry for the noise, but I misspoke when I said they SDF was only needed for the file path. We do need the original SDF of Models and Worlds for saving worlds to SDF. So, if you're okay with `InitialModelSdf`, I'll proceed with that.
content.html:
Yeah, that's a valid concern. I was not thinking ModelSdf will be kept up to date, so calling it InitialModelSdf makes sense. On further thought, maybe we should stick with creating a component for <self_collide>. My reason for adding ModelSdf for saving world files was to retrieve the SDF's file path, but that can be kept in a SdfFilePath component. I also now realize that we won't be able to properly serialize sdf::Model because it needs a pointer to it's sdf::World for frame semantics.

Edit: Sorry for the noise, but I misspoke when I said they SDF was only needed for the file path. We do need the original SDF of Models and Worlds for saving worlds to SDF. So, if you're okay with InitialModelSdf, I'll proceed with that.

content.raw: The only concern I have is about all the duplicate data that is also present on other components. Is any system going to keep `ModelSdf` up-to-date? Should it be called `InitialModelSdf` instead?
content.html: The only concern I have is about all the duplicate data that is also present on other components. Is any system going to keep ModelSdf up-to-date? Should it be called InitialModelSdf instead?

content.raw: @{557058:6ff86fcb-b7ab-44a5-b8a6-f6d9cae8b6e8}, are you okay with storing the SDF DOM object? I need to do the same thing for saving world files so I went ahead and did it here as well instead of creating a component for `<self_collide>`.
content.html: @Louise Poubel, are you okay with storing the SDF DOM object? I need to do the same thing for saving world files so I went ahead and did it here as well instead of creating a component for <self_collide>.

content.raw:
I found that the error occurs if the models were in collision to begin with. Moving them farther apart eliminates the error and the vehicle collides with the breadcrumbs. 

![good_collision.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1486288225-good_collision.gif)

I tried PR #104. It still has the LCP error if the models start in collision. After I positioned them so they don't start in collision, the breadcrumbs don't seem to collide with anything including the ground.

![no_collide.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/919704885-no_collide.gif)
content.html:
I found that the error occurs if the models were in collision to begin with. Moving them farther apart eliminates the error and the vehicle collides with the breadcrumbs.

I tried PR #104. It still has the LCP error if the models start in collision. After I positioned them so they don't start in collision, the breadcrumbs don't seem to collide with anything including the ground.

content.raw:
So we weren't passing along the `<self_collide>` attribute to ign-physics. I went ahead and fixed that but now I get

```
Error [BoxedLcpConstraintSolver.cpp:294] [BoxedLcpConstraintSolver] The solution of LCP includes NAN values: -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan    0 -nan    0    0 -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan    0 -nan    0 -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan. We're setting it zero for safety. Consider using more robust solver such as PGS as a secondary solver. If this happens even with PGS solver, please report this as a bug.
```
I'm still investigating.
content.html:
So we weren't passing along the <self_collide> attribute to ign-physics. I went ahead and fixed that but now I get

Error [BoxedLcpConstraintSolver.cpp:294] [BoxedLcpConstraintSolver] The solution of LCP includes NAN values: -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan    0 -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan    0 -nan    0    0 -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan    0 -nan    0 -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan -nan. We're setting it zero for safety. Consider using more robust solver such as PGS as a secondary solver. If this happens even with PGS solver, please report this as a bug.

I'm still investigating.

content.raw:
it looks like self-collide is off by default within a dart skeleton

* https://github.com/dartsim/dart/blob/master/dart/dynamics/detail/SkeletonAspect.hpp#L69-L84
content.html:
it looks like self-collide is off by default within a dart skeleton

content.raw:
until we support `WeldJointConstraint` in the ign-physics-dartsim plugin, if you want a vehicle to hold multiple breadcrumbs, then the vehicle should be the parent of those joints

the plugin could be part of either model, but the vehicle should be the parent of the joint if we are limited to a tree topology
content.html:
until we support WeldJointConstraint in the ign-physics-dartsim plugin, if you want a vehicle to hold multiple breadcrumbs, then the vehicle should be the parent of those joints

the plugin could be part of either model, but the vehicle should be the parent of the joint if we are limited to a tree topology

content.raw:
> the sdf parameter look like the plugin needs to be in the parent model

I guess my thinking is that the parent model is whichever model that has the plugin. I don't really see a reason why the vehicle should be the parent and the child be the breadcrumb. The opposite should be fine too. At least, that's what I would want as a user of the system.

> if we set self_collide = true in the bread-crumb models, does that fix it?

No, that didn't work. I tried putting it in all of the models and that still didn't work.
content.html:
the sdf parameter look like the plugin needs to be in the parent model

I guess my thinking is that the parent model is whichever model that has the plugin. I don't really see a reason why the vehicle should be the parent and the child be the breadcrumb. The opposite should be fine too. At least, that's what I would want as a user of the system.

if we set self_collide = true in the bread-crumb models, does that fix it?

No, that didn't work. I tried putting it in all of the models and that still didn't work.

content.raw:
but regarding `self_collide`, yes it would be more straightforward to use `WeldJointConstraint`

if we set `self_collide = true` in the bread-crumb models, does that fix it?
content.html:
but regarding self_collide, yes it would be more straightforward to use WeldJointConstraint

if we set self_collide = true in the bread-crumb models, does that fix it?

content.raw:
the sdf parameter look like the plugin needs to be in the parent model

if we want it to be in the child model, we should specify `parent_model` as an sdf parameter instead of `child_model`
content.html:
the sdf parameter look like the plugin needs to be in the parent model

if we want it to be in the child model, we should specify parent_model as an sdf parameter instead of child_model

content.raw:
I'm liking the idea of using `WeldJointConstraint` more and more. The issue I see now is that a detached model cannot collide with the model it was detached from. Maybe it would work if both models had `self_collide` on, but that's not always feasible.

![no_self_collide.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/904027186-no_self_collide.gif)

With the example I added, I tried putting the plugin in the breadcrumb models, but that only worked for 1 breadcrumb. For the other two, the joint was not created because the child now has a parent joint from the first breadcrumb.
content.html:
I'm liking the idea of using WeldJointConstraint more and more. The issue I see now is that a detached model cannot collide with the model it was detached from. Maybe it would work if both models had self_collide on, but that's not always feasible.

With the example I added, I tried putting the plugin in the breadcrumb models, but that only worked for 1 breadcrumb. For the other two, the joint was not created because the child now has a parent joint from the first breadcrumb.

content.raw:
it can be attached anywhere on the parent, but if the child doesn't have a FreeJoint, then we need to use a `WeldJointConstraint`

if you call moveTo on something without a FreeJoint, it will delete it's other parent joint

it's similar to the issue with closed-loop kinematic chains
content.html:
it can be attached anywhere on the parent, but if the child doesn't have a FreeJoint, then we need to use a WeldJointConstraint

if you call moveTo on something without a FreeJoint, it will delete it's other parent joint

it's similar to the issue with closed-loop kinematic chains

content.raw: Yeah, I'll add a check. But it made me ask why does the child have to have a FreeJoint? Should we not be able to attach an independent kinematic chain to another chain (anywhere on the chain) without forming a loop?
content.html: Yeah, I'll add a check. But it made me ask why does the child have to have a FreeJoint? Should we not be able to attach an independent kinematic chain to another chain (anywhere on the chain) without forming a loop?

content.raw: thanks, sorry I missed that todo
content.html: thanks, sorry I missed that todo

content.raw: nice work, this is looking pretty good
content.html: nice work, this is looking pretty good

content.raw:
I think we need to check the `jointPtrPhys` pointer before using it, right? If the child link does not have a FreeJoint, then I think it won't attach properly

not a bad idea for a test
content.html:
I think we need to check the jointPtrPhys pointer before using it, right? If the child link does not have a FreeJoint, then I think it won't attach properly

not a bad idea for a test

content.raw: I had left a todo about using Empty. I didn't use it because I thought there was no way to publish an Empty from the command line. I just found out that you can do "unused: true" to publish Empty msgs with `ign topic`, so I've changed this to Empty in b9bd9cf.
content.html: I had left a todo about using Empty. I didn't use it because I thought there was no way to publish an Empty from the command line. I just found out that you can do "unused: true" to publish Empty msgs with ign topic, so I've changed this to Empty in b9bd9cf.
